moves.1. e3: An uncommon opening, that gives Black at least equality.
moves.1... e5 2. d4 e4 3. c4: Discouraging ... d5, which can still be played: 3. ... d5 4. cxd5 Qxd5 5. Nc3 Bb4
moves.4. Nc3 Bb4: This is an improved version of the Nimzo-Indian, because the e4 pawn prevents both Bd3 and Nf3.
moves.5. f3: White should play Nge2 followed by a kingside fianchetto or Ng3, Be2, and 0-0.
moves.6. bxc3 O-O 7. fxe4 Nxe4 8. Nf3:
Preventing ... Qh4
Nxc3 isn't a threat because Qc2 traps the knight.
moves.8... Re8 9. Qc2 d6 10. Bd3 Bf5 11. O-O B: The King was better on g1.
moves.12... Nd7 13. Ba3: The bishop does nothing on a3.
moves.13... Nb6: Threatening ... Nxc4 followed by ... Ng3+, winning the Queen
moves.16. a4 h5: Provoking h4, which loses to ... Ng3+
moves.17. Nd2 Nxe3: The most forcing continuation, since the Queen is under attack.
